details.title: Inference for a Simple Step-Stress Model With Type-II Censoring, and Weibull Distributed Lifetimes
details.standardTitle: Inference for a Simple Step-Stress Model With Type-II Censoring, and Weibull Distributed Lifetimes

p: Maria Kateri is an Assistant Professor of Statistics at the University of Piraeus, Greece. She received her Diploma in Mathematics from the University of Ioannina, Greece, in 1989; her M.Phil. in Statistics from University of Strathclyde, U.K. in 1992; and her Ph.D. from the Department of Mathematics, University of Ioannina, Greece, in 1996. Her research interests include categorical data analysis, biostatistics, Bayesian analysis, and reliability.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Stat. & Insurance Sci., Univ. of Piraeus, Piraeus
authors.name: Maria Kateri

p: Narayanaswamy Balakrishnan is a Professor of Statistics at McMaster University, Hamilton, Ontario, Canada. He received his B.Sc., and M.Sc. degrees in Statistics From the University of Madras, India, in 1976, and 1978, respectively. He finished his Ph.D. in Statistics from Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, India, in 1981. He is a Fellow of the American Statistical Association, and a Fellow of the Institute of Mathematical Statistics. He is currently the Editor-in-Chief of Communications in Statistics, and Executive Editor of Journal of Statistical Planning and Inference. His research interests include distribution theory, ordered data analysis, censoring methodology, reliability, survival analysis, and statistical quality control.

details.abstract: The simple step-stress model under type-II censoring based on Weibull lifetimes, which provides a more flexible model than the exponential model, is considered in this paper. For this model, the maximum likelihood estimates (MLE) of its parameters, as well as the corresponding observed Fisher information matrix, are derived. The likelihood equations do not lead to closed-form expressions for the MLE, and they need to be solved by using an iterative procedure, such as the Newton-Raphson method. We also present a simplified estimator, which is easier to compute, and hence is suitable to use as an initial estimate in the iterative process for the determination of the MLE. We then evaluate the bias, and mean square error of these estimates; and provide asymptotic, and bootstrap confidence intervals for the parameters of the Weibull simple step-stress model. Finally, the results are illustrated with some examples.

Thus, under the assumption of the cumulative exposure model, the CDF of the lifetime of a test unit under such a simple step-stress model is given by where \$s\$ is the solution of the equation \$F_{2}(s)=F_{1}(\tau)\$ (see Bagdonavicius & Nikulin [1], p. 22), and \$F_{j}(x)=1-e^{-(x/\theta_{j})^{\beta}}\$ is the CDF of the Weibull distribution \$W(\theta_{j},\beta),\,j=1,2\$.

links.abstract: The authors present the optimum simple time-step and failure-step stress accelerated life tests for the case where a prespecified censoring time is involved. An exponential life distribution with a mean that is a log-linear function of stress, and a cumulative exposure model are assumed. The authors obtain the optimum test plans to minimize the asymptotic variance of the maximum-likelihood estimator of the mean life at a design stress. Nomographs for the optimum time-step stress test are also gi...

context.text:
We describe next the procedure of obtaining a bootstrap confidence interval in the present context using the bias corrected accelerated \$({\rm BC}a)\$ percentile method (see Efron & Tibshirani [6], pp. 182-184):

1)Obtain the MLE \$\hat{\theta}_{1},\,\hat{\theta}_{2}\$, and \$\hat{\beta}\$ of the corresponding parameters, based on the initial sample \${\bf t}=(t_{1:n},t_{2:n},\ldots,t_{r:n})\$.
2)Simulate the first \$r\$ order statistics from a data sample of size \$n\$ from a simple step-stress model with Type-II censored Weibull lifetimes using \$\hat{\theta}_{1},\,\hat{\theta}_{2}\$, and \$\hat{\beta}\$ as the parameters (details are provided in Appendix B).
3)Estimate the parameter vector \${\mbi \theta}=(\theta_{1},\theta_{2},\theta_{3})=(\theta_{1},\theta_{2},\beta)\$ from the new simulated data set.
4)Repeat steps 2 and 3, \$B\$ times, and obtain thus \$\hat{\mbi \theta}^{(1)},\hat{\mbi \theta}^{(2)},\ldots,\hat{\mbi \theta}^{(B)}\$, where \$\hat{\mbi \theta}^{(k)}=(\hat{\theta}_{1}^{(k)},\hat{\theta}_{2}^{(k)},\hat{\theta}_{3}^{(k)})=(\hat{\theta}_{1}^{(k)},\hat{\theta}_{2}^{(k)},\hat{\beta}^{(k)}),\,k=1,\ldots,B\$.
5)For each parameter, arrange its bootstrap sample in ascending order, and obtain \$\hat{\theta}_{i}^{[1]},\hat{\theta}_{i}^{[2]},\ldots\hat{\theta}_{i}^{[B]}(i=1,2,3)\$.

links.abstract: This paper presents optimum plans for simple (two stresses) step-stress tests where all units are run to failure. Such plans minimize the asymptotic variance of the maximum likelihood estimator (MLE) of the mean life at a design stress. The life-test model consists of: 1) an exponential life distribution with 2) a mean that is a log-linear function of stress, and 3) a cumulative exposure model for the effect of changing stress. Two types of simple step-stress tests are considered: 1) a time-step...

links.abstract: This paper presents the inferences of parameters on the simple step-stress model in accelerated life testing with type-II censoring. An exponential life distribution with a mean that is a log-linear function of stress, and a cumulative exposure model are assumed. Maximum likelihood methods are used to estimate the parameters of these models. Hypothesis tests about model parameters are discussed. Confidence intervals for parameter-estimates are constructed using a pivotal quantity. The advantage ...

context.text: Xiong [14], Xiong & Milliken [15], and Balakrishnan et al. [5] have all considered inferences for the step-stress model assuming exponential lifetimes based on complete, and Type-II censored samples; while Balakrishnan & Xie [3], [4] have developed exact inference based on hybrid censored samples for the exponential case.

Specifically, we consider initially a data set (Table V) of small sample size \$(n=20)\$, simulated from the exponential simple step-stress model, provided earlier by Xiong [14], and further analyzed by Balakrishnan et al. [5].

links.abstract: This paper studies statistical models in step-stress accelerated life-testing when the stress-change times are random. The marginal lifetime distribution of a test unit under a step-stress test plan when the stress change times are random variables is presented. Maximum likelihood estimates for model parameters based on both the marginal and conditional life distributions are considered. An optimum test plan is explored for simple step-stress test when the stress change time is an order statisti...
